To this group must be added a station in Washington, D. C.
probably the present WAMU-FM or the upcoming (Spring 1969)
WETA-FM. This affiliation must be explored. It is our
understanding that Mr. Holt in his radio study for the
Ford Foundation and the CPB is looking into the Washington
situation as well as those in Los Angeles, Chicago, and
Detroit. His guidance and data will be helpful.
It has been suggested that, in addition to these
large cities it might be useful to test this model system
for audience reaction in a less urban or rural area. The
author believes that The Wisconsin State Network might
provide such a test point for the system. If Wisconsin
were interested it would also test a full range of audience
response among different population groupings due to
the state-wide coverage by that network. Their facilities
and operating performance are excellent, as Mr. Holtâ€™s
study attests.
VI Cost of the System
The cost of an initial National Public Radio System
would consist primarily of:
(a) Headquarters facilities
(b) Interconnection Circuits
(c) Tape distribution to Basic Stations
(d) Program and Production Costs including
talent fees, permanent program and production personnel,
and related production expenses.
(e) Length of the experimental model (Note:
Mr. Frank Gillard of the BBC suggests strongly the need
"to have a long run, of three or four years perhaps,
before evaluation . . .It takes time to wean people away
from existing and.long-established listening habits and
to get them to reorient themselves on a completely new
service*')
